Award.AwardTitle: Recruiting and Keeping Undergraduate Students in the Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The College of Science at the University of Texas-El Paso (UTEP) is to offer 12 S-STEM scholarships, to talented freshmen in financial need, who major in the disciplines of biology, chemistry, mathematics, geology and physics. The scholarship is to be up to $10,000 per year for two years. The focus is to be on recruiting Hispanic scholars from local high schools in the community, who demonstrate an aptitude for science. Scholarships are to carry students over the first two years of their degree plan, i.e. to reach junior status in the 4 year institution. In the case of selected scholars not meeting the financial need status for a $10,000 scholarship, more scholarships are to be offered. In addition to a direct financial scholarship the students are to be immediately housed in the University Student Village so that they become immersed in the College experience. In addition, the incoming S-STEM freshmen student cohort of 6 is to be enrolled in a Learning Community with other incoming students who declare the same major. The Learning Community involves a University Seminar class, which will be major specific. Each of the Scholars is also to be enrolled in the same Introduction to Research class every semester during their freshman and sophomore years. The second year students will automatically become peer leaders/guides to their incoming colleagues. Students are prepared for and will be encouraged to engage in undergraduate research. The faculty member with whom they choose to do research will be their mentor and advisor until graduation. The intent is to graduate at least 30 students in 4-5 years who will then go to graduate school. The request is $550,381 for five years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "experiment" focused upon using this grant was designed to overcome the significant drop-out rate during the first two years of college that we, and others in higher education, identify as a key factor associated with non-graduation in the STEM disciplines. The hypothesis was that successfully navigating these first two years would propel the student to graduation in a timely  manner.

In our program we provided a two year scholarship of <$10,000 per year to local students, mandated they reside on campus for those two years, assigned them a faculty tutor as a guide to the university environment, and set up a weekly meeting with the PD and other STEM professionals to discuss STEM careers and strategies for success. We also mandated the students participate in an annual retreat involving senior UG students outside the NSF Program reporting on their own research activities from previous years.

These simple interventions, in an urban university with a predominantly low income family background, resulted in much quicker time to graduation with a significantly higher cumulative GPA when compared to their equivalent year by year entry cohort. Indeed, to date,  ~86% of the students in the program have graduated in an average of 4.3 years, which compares to a 40% completion for the comparison cohort. For all incoming students the graduation rate is ~40% after 6 years. There has been zero drop out by our NSF scholars and only one, 3%, changed to a non-STEM major.

Since the activities were not discipline directed, the results hold great promise for all areas of study in institutions of higher learning. The results have also reinforced our University goal of creating more student housing.

In an age where a well-educated work force be science literate to maintain our national competitiveness, our results illustrate a relatively simple, effective and affordable pathway to increasing the pool of such persons. This is particularly important in urban settings with low income student body.
